content.webTitle: The Pains of Being Pure at Heart: Belong – review

fields.headline: The Pains of Being Pure at Heart: Belong – review
fields.bodyText: The Brooklyn indiepop bands who emerged a couple of years ago are now facing the same test their British mid-80s forebears faced and, in the main, failed: how do you build a career when your very reason for being was to make a single statement in opposition to the pop culture around you? The Pains of Being Pure at Heart opt to adapt, drafting in producer Flood and mixer Alan Moulder to polish and shine their second album. They nearly succeed: the title track is a valiant attempt at recreating My Bloody Valentine's eureka moment, when four-chord thrash suddenly became something odder and more interesting. Even In Dreams has the palm-muted guitar throb and keyboard washes of AM guitar pop before the wall of sound crashes in on the chorus. But Kip Berman's voice – breathy if you're kind, weedy if you're not – isn't actually suited to much other than fey jangling, and acts as a brake on the group's ambitions throughout.
